batch.name: Class 11 - Chapter 5: Morphology of Flowering Plants

questions.question: Pneumatophores are found in:
questions.explanation: Pneumatophores (breathing roots) are found in mangrove plants like Rhizophora. They grow vertically upward from the ground to help in gaseous exchange in waterlogged, anaerobic soil.

questions.question: Phyllotaxy in which more than two leaves arise at a node is called:
questions.explanation: Whorled phyllotaxy is the arrangement in which more than two leaves arise at a node and form a whorl, as seen in Alstonia.

questions.question: Which type of placentation is found in mustard and Argemone?
questions.explanation: Parietal placentation is found in mustard (Brassicaceae) and Argemone. In this type, the ovules develop on the inner wall of the ovary or on peripheral part, and the ovary is one-chambered but becomes two-chambered due to formation of a false septum.

questions.question: Fibrous root system is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Fibrous root system is characteristic of monocotyledons. In this system, the primary root is short-lived and is replaced by a large number of roots arising from the base of the stem.

questions.question: Racemose inflorescence is characterised by:
options: C) Oldest flowers at the top
B) Main axis continuing to grow indefinitely
A) Main axis terminating in a flower
D) Flowers opening from top to bottom
questions.explanation: In racemose inflorescence, the main axis continues to grow and flowers are borne laterally in acropetal succession. The oldest flowers are at the base and youngest at the tip.

questions.question: Aestivation in which the margins of sepals or petals overlap one another but not in any particular direction is called:
questions.explanation: In imbricate aestivation, the margins of sepals or petals overlap one another but not in any definite direction. In twisted aestivation, one margin overlaps the next and so on.

questions.question: In Fabaceae (pea family), the aestivation is:
questions.explanation: In Fabaceae, the corolla shows vexillary (descending imbricate) aestivation. The largest petal (standard/vexillum) overlaps the two lateral petals (wings/alae), which in turn overlap the two smallest anterior petals (keel/carina).

questions.question: The stem modification found in ginger is:
questions.explanation: Ginger has a rhizome, which is an underground stem that grows horizontally. It has nodes, internodes, and scale leaves. Other examples of rhizomes include turmeric and banana.

questions.question: Marginal placentation is found in:
questions.explanation: Marginal placentation is found in pea (Pisum sativum), a member of Fabaceae. In marginal placentation, the placenta forms a ridge along the ventral suture of the ovary and the ovules are borne on this ridge.

questions.question: The edible part of a coconut is:
questions.explanation: The edible part of coconut is the endosperm. The white flesh is the cellular endosperm and the coconut water is the liquid endosperm (nuclear endosperm).

questions.question: Prop roots are found in:
questions.explanation: Prop roots (pillar roots) are found in the banyan tree (Ficus benghalensis). They arise from horizontal aerial branches and grow downward to the soil, providing additional support to the heavy branches.

questions.question: Compound leaves with leaflets attached at a common point like fingers of a hand are called:
questions.explanation: In palmately compound leaves, the leaflets are attached at a common point (the tip of the petiole), resembling the spread fingers of a hand. Example: silk cotton (Bombax).

questions.question: Which of the following fruits is a drupe?
questions.explanation: Mango is a drupe, a type of simple fleshy fruit with a stony endocarp. The fruit wall is differentiated into an outer epicarp (skin), fleshy mesocarp (edible part), and hard stony endocarp (pit/stone).

questions.question: Tendrils in Cucurbita (cucumber) are modifications of:
questions.explanation: In Cucurbita (cucumber family), the tendrils are modifications of stems. They arise from axillary buds and help the plant in climbing.

questions.question: The floral formula for Solanaceae is:
options: D) Zygomorphic, bisexual, K(5), C1+2+(2), A(9)+1, G1
B) Zygomorphic, bisexual, K5, C5, A10, G1
A) Actinomorphic, bisexual, K(5), C(5), A5, G(2)
C) Actinomorphic, bisexual, K5, C5, A5, G(3)
questions.explanation: Solanaceae flowers are actinomorphic, bisexual, with 5 fused sepals K(5), 5 fused petals C(5), 5 free stamens attached to petals A5, and a bicarpellary syncarpous superior ovary G(2).

questions.question: Stilt roots are found in:
questions.explanation: Stilt roots are adventitious roots that arise from the lower nodes of the stem and enter the soil obliquely to provide additional support. They are found in maize and sugarcane.

questions.question: Which type of venation is found in monocotyledons?
questions.explanation: Parallel venation is characteristic of monocotyledons. In parallel venation, the veins run parallel to each other within the lamina. Examples include grass, maize, and bamboo.

questions.question: In Fabaceae, the stamens are:
questions.explanation: In Fabaceae (Papilionaceae), the stamens are diadelphous, meaning they are united into two bundles. Typically, 9 stamens are fused and 1 stamen is free (9)+1 arrangement.

questions.question: Free central placentation is found in:
questions.explanation: Free central placentation is found in Dianthus, Primrose (Primula), and other members of Caryophyllaceae and Primulaceae. In this type, ovules are borne on the central axis without any septum.

questions.question: The underground stem modification in potato is:
questions.explanation: Potato has stem tubers. The stem branches grow underground, swell at the tips and form tubers. The 'eyes' of the potato are nodes with axillary buds.

questions.question: Epipetalous stamens are found in:
questions.explanation: In Solanaceae, the stamens are epipetalous, meaning they are attached to the petals. There are 5 stamens alternating with the petals.

questions.question: Cymose inflorescence is characterised by:
options: A) Unlimited growth of the main axis
B) Main axis terminating in a flower
questions.explanation: In cymose inflorescence, the main axis terminates in a flower, and hence it has limited growth. The flowers open in basipetal succession or centrifugal order (from centre to periphery).

questions.question: In Liliaceae, the perianth is:
options: C) Undifferentiated (tepals), 6 in two whorls of 3 each
A) Differentiated into calyx and corolla
questions.explanation: In Liliaceae, the perianth is not differentiated into distinct sepals and petals. Instead, it consists of 6 tepals arranged in two whorls of 3 each (3+3). The tepals are often petaloid.

questions.question: A flower that can be divided into two equal halves only in one plane is called:
questions.explanation: A zygomorphic (bilateral symmetry) flower can be divided into two equal halves only in one vertical plane. Examples include pea, bean, and Cassia. Actinomorphic flowers can be divided into equal halves in any radial plane.

questions.question: Sweet potato is a modification of:
questions.explanation: Sweet potato (Ipomoea batatas) is a modification of adventitious roots for food storage. Unlike potato, which is a stem tuber, sweet potato is a root tuber. It lacks nodes and internodes.

questions.question: Axile placentation is found in:
questions.explanation: Axile placentation is found in China rose (Hibiscus), tomato, lemon, and other plants with syncarpous ovary having septa. The ovules are borne on the central axis where septa meet.

questions.question: Bulb is a type of stem modification found in:
questions.explanation: Onion and garlic have bulbs, which are underground stem modifications. A bulb has a short disc-like stem surrounded by fleshy scale leaves that store food. The stem is highly reduced.

questions.question: An aggregate fruit develops from:
options: A) A single ovary of a flower
questions.explanation: An aggregate fruit (etaerio) develops from a multicarpellary, apocarpous gynoecium of a single flower. Each free carpel develops into a fruitlet. Example: Annona (custard apple) and strawberry.

questions.question: Thorns are modified stems found in:
questions.explanation: In Bougainvillea and Citrus, thorns are stem modifications that arise in the axil of leaves. They are woody, pointed, and help in protection. In contrast, the spines of Barberry are leaf modifications.

questions.question: The corm is a stem modification found in:
questions.explanation: Colocasia (arbi/taro) has a corm, which is a short, swollen underground stem that grows vertically and stores food. It has distinct nodes and internodes, with scale leaves at nodes.

questions.question: Valvate aestivation is found in:
questions.explanation: In valvate aestivation, the margins of sepals or petals just touch each other without overlapping. This is found in Calotropis. China rose shows twisted aestivation, pea shows vexillary, and Cassia shows imbricate.

questions.question: In a seed, the outer covering derived from the integuments is called:
questions.explanation: The seed coat is derived from the integuments of the ovule. The outer seed coat is called testa and the inner is called tegmen. They protect the embryo within.

questions.question: Phylloclades (flattened photosynthetic stems) are found in:
questions.explanation: In Opuntia (prickly pear cactus), the stem is modified into flattened, green, photosynthetic structures called phylloclades. The leaves are reduced to spines to reduce water loss.

questions.question: The placentation in Solanaceae is:
questions.explanation: The placentation in Solanaceae is axile. The ovary is bilocular (two-chambered) with a swollen placenta bearing many ovules.

questions.question: Which modification of tap root is found in turnip?
questions.explanation: Turnip has a napiform root, which is roughly spherical at the top and suddenly tapers at the lower end. Carrot has a conical root, and radish has a fusiform root.

questions.question: Twisted or contorted aestivation is found in:
questions.explanation: Twisted (contorted) aestivation is found in China rose (Hibiscus). In this type, one margin of each petal overlaps the margin of the adjacent petal regularly, so that each petal has one margin overlapping and the other overlapped.

questions.question: The flattened leaf-like petiole that performs photosynthesis is called:
questions.explanation: A phyllode is a modified flattened petiole that takes over the function of photosynthesis. It is found in Australian Acacia, where the lamina is reduced or absent.

questions.question: The scar left on the seed after the stalk (funicle) detaches is called:
questions.explanation: The hilum is the scar on the seed coat through which the developing seed was attached to the fruit via the funicle (stalk). It marks the point of attachment of the seed to the fruit.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Potato is a stem modification, not a root modification.
Reason (R): Potato has nodes (eyes) and internodes and can give rise to new plants from the buds present in the eyes.
options: C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Potato is a stem tuber because it possesses characteristics of stems: nodes (eyes), internodes, axillary buds, and scale leaves. These features distinguish it from root tubers like sweet potato.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In pea, tendrils are modifications of leaves.
Reason (R): In pea, the upper leaflets of the compound leaf are modified into tendrils for climbing.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: In pea (Pisum sativum), the terminal leaflets of the pinnately compound leaf are modified into tendrils that help in climbing. This is a leaf modification for support.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Fabaceae shows marginal placentation.
Reason (R): In Fabaceae, the ovary is monocarpellary with ovules attached to the ventral suture.
options: D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Fabaceae has marginal placentation where the ovary is monocarpellary (single carpel) and the ovules are borne on the ventral suture (margin) of the ovary. The placenta forms a ridge along the ventral suture.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The flowers of Solanaceae are actinomorphic.
Reason (R): Actinomorphic flowers can be divided into two equal halves in any radial plane passing through the centre.
options: C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. Solanaceae flowers are actinomorphic (radially symmetrical). The definition of actinomorphic is also correct. However, the reason defines actinomorphic but does not explain WHY Solanaceae flowers are actinomorphic.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Banyan tree has adventitious roots hanging from branches.
Reason (R): These prop roots provide mechanical support to the heavy spreading branches of the banyan tree.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: The banyan tree has prop roots (pillar roots) that are adventitious roots growing from horizontal branches downward into the soil. They provide mechanical support to the massive spreading canopy.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In Opuntia, the leaves are modified into spines.
Reason (R): The flattened green stems (phylloclades) take over the function of photosynthesis in Opuntia.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both statements are true. In Opuntia, leaves are reduced to spines to reduce transpiration, and stems are modified into flattened phylloclades that perform photosynthesis. However, the stem being a phylloclade is not the reason for leaf modification into spines; both are adaptations to arid conditions.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In Liliaceae, the stamens are 6 and arranged in two whorls.
Reason (R): Liliaceae is a monocotyledonous family with trimerous flowers.
options: C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: In Liliaceae, there are 6 stamens in two whorls of 3+3 (androecium). This is because Liliaceae is a monocot family, and monocots characteristically have trimerous flowers (floral parts in multiples of 3).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The radish root is fusiform in shape.
Reason (R): A fusiform root is thickest in the middle and tapers towards both ends.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The radish (Raphanus sativus) has a fusiform (spindle-shaped) tap root modification. It is widest in the middle and tapers towards both the top and bottom ends.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): A composite fruit develops from an entire inflorescence.
Reason (R): In a composite fruit, individual fruits fuse together to form a single mass.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) Both A and R are false
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: A composite (multiple) fruit develops from the entire inflorescence, where the individual fruits of the inflorescence fuse together along with other floral parts to form a single mass. Examples: pineapple (sorosis) and fig (syconus).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Maize has a fibrous root system.
Reason (R): In maize, the primary root is long-lived and forms the main root system.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Maize (a monocot) has a fibrous root system. However, the reason is false because in monocots, the primary root is short-lived and is replaced by a cluster of adventitious roots arising from the base of the stem.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Alternate phyllotaxy is found in sunflower and mustard.
Reason (R): In alternate phyllotaxy, a single leaf arises at each node alternately on either side of the stem.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both sunflower and mustard show alternate phyllotaxy. In this arrangement, a single leaf is produced at each node in an alternating pattern, giving a spiral appearance.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The pitcher in Nepenthes is a leaf modification.
Reason (R): The leaf lamina is modified into a pitcher to trap insects for nitrogen.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: In Nepenthes (pitcher plant), the leaf is modified into a pitcher-like structure to trap and digest insects. This is an adaptation to nitrogen-poor soils; the insects provide supplementary nitrogen.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Perigynous flowers have a half-inferior ovary.
Reason (R): In perigynous flowers, the gynoecium is situated in the centre and other floral parts are located on the rim of the thalamus at the same level.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: In perigynous flowers, the thalamus grows upward to form a cup-shaped structure. The gynoecium is at the base of the cup, and other floral parts arise from the rim, making the ovary half-inferior (semi-inferior). Examples: plum, rose, peach.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about root modifications:
(i) Carrot has a conical root.
(ii) Radish has a fusiform root.
(iii) Turnip has a napiform root.
(iv) Sweet potato has a modified tap root.
How many statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Carrot is conical, radish is fusiform, and turnip is napiform. Statement (iv) is incorrect because sweet potato is a modification of adventitious roots, not tap root.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about Fabaceae is INCORRECT?
(i) Flowers are zygomorphic.
(ii) Corolla is papilionaceous.
(iii) Stamens are monadelphous.
(iv) Fruit is a legume or pod.
questions.explanation: Statement (iii) is incorrect. In Fabaceae (Papilionaceae), the stamens are diadelphous (9+1), not monadelphous. Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are all correct features of Fabaceae.

questions.question:
Read the following statements about Solanaceae:
Statement I: Flowers are actinomorphic and bisexual.
Statement II: Calyx and corolla are each five-lobed and fused.
Statement III: Ovary is tricarpellary and trilocular.
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements I and II are correct. Solanaceae flowers are actinomorphic, bisexual, with 5 fused sepals and 5 fused petals. Statement III is incorrect; the ovary is bicarpellary (two carpels) and bilocular (two-chambered), not tricarpellary.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about underground stem modifications:
(i) Rhizome grows horizontally underground (e.g., ginger).
(ii) Tuber is a swollen tip of an underground stem (e.g., potato).
(iii) Bulb has a reduced discoid stem surrounded by fleshy leaves (e.g., onion).
(iv) Corm grows vertically underground (e.g., colocasia).
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct descriptions of underground stem modifications as per NCERT. Rhizome (ginger), tuber (potato), bulb (onion), and corm (colocasia) are all stem modifications found underground.

questions.question:
How many of the following statements about Liliaceae are correct?
(i) Plants are mostly perennial herbs with bulbs or rhizomes.
(ii) Flowers have 6 tepals in two whorls.
(iii) Ovary is superior and tricarpellary.
(iv) The fruit is usually a capsule or berry.
(v) Leaves show reticulate venation.
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (v) is incorrect because Liliaceae, being monocots, show parallel venation, not reticulate venation.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about inflorescence types is correct?
Statement 1: In raceme, flowers are borne on pedicels along an elongated axis.
Statement 2: In spike, sessile flowers are borne on an elongated axis.
Statement 3: In umbel, flowers arise from the same point.
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Raceme has pedicellate flowers on an elongated axis (e.g., mustard). Spike has sessile flowers on an elongated axis (e.g., Achyranthes). Umbel has flowers arising from a common point (e.g., Centella).

questions.question:
Select the INCORRECT statement about seed structure:
(i) The hilum is the point where the seed is attached to the fruit.
(ii) The micropyle is a small pore for water absorption.
(iii) The embryo consists of radicle, plumule, and cotyledons.
(iv) Endosperm is always present in mature seeds.
questions.explanation: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Endosperm is not always present in mature seeds. In non-endospermic (exalbuminous) seeds like pea and bean, the endosperm is consumed during seed development and food is stored in cotyledons.

questions.question:
Read the following statements about placentation:
I. Marginal: ovules on ventral suture (e.g., pea)
II. Axile: ovules on central axis of multilocular ovary (e.g., tomato)
III. Parietal: ovules on inner wall of ovary (e.g., mustard)
IV. Basal: single ovule at the base (e.g., sunflower)
How many are correct?
questions.explanation: All four statements correctly describe the respective types of placentation with accurate examples. Marginal in pea, axile in tomato, parietal in mustard, and basal in sunflower (Compositae) are all correctly matched.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about leaf modifications is INCORRECT?
(i) Tendrils of pea are modified leaflets.
(ii) Spines of Opuntia are modified leaves.
(iii) The pitcher of Nepenthes is a modified leaf.
(iv) Phyllode of Australian Acacia is a modified stipule.
questions.explanation: Statement (iv) is incorrect. The phyllode of Australian Acacia is a modified petiole (not stipule) that becomes flattened and green to perform photosynthesis. Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct.

questions.question:
Consider the following about the monocot seed:
(i) It has a single cotyledon called scutellum.
(ii) The endosperm is present and stores food.
(iii) The embryo has an epicotyl covered by coleoptile.
(iv) The radicle is covered by coleorhiza.
Which are correct?
questions.explanation: All four statements are correct for a monocot seed (e.g., maize). The single cotyledon is called scutellum. Endosperm is present. The embryonal axis has an epicotyl with a coleoptile and a radicle covered by coleorhiza.

questions.question:
How many of the following represent stem modifications?
(i) Potato (ii) Ginger (iii) Sweet potato (iv) Onion (v) Colocasia (vi) Carrot
questions.explanation: Potato (tuber), Ginger (rhizome), Onion (bulb), and Colocasia (corm) are stem modifications. Sweet potato and Carrot are root modifications, not stem modifications.

questions.question:
Match the stem modifications with their examples:
Column I: (a) Rhizome (b) Tuber (c) Bulb (d) Corm
Column II: (i) Potato (ii) Ginger (iii) Colocasia (iv) Onion
questions.explanation: Rhizome - Ginger, Tuber - Potato, Bulb - Onion, Corm - Colocasia. These are the four types of underground stem modifications.

questions.question:
Match the placentation types with their examples:
Column I: (a) Marginal (b) Axile (c) Parietal (d) Free central (e) Basal
Column II: (i) Mustard (ii) Pea (iii) China rose (iv) Sunflower (v) Dianthus
options: C) a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-v, e-iv
B) a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv, e-v
D) a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-iv, e-v
A) a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-v, e-iv
questions.explanation: Marginal - Pea, Axile - China rose, Parietal - Mustard, Free central - Dianthus, Basal - Sunflower.

questions.question:
Match the root modifications with their examples:
Column I: (a) Conical (b) Fusiform (c) Napiform (d) Pneumatophores
Column II: (i) Turnip (ii) Rhizophora (iii) Radish (iv) Carrot
questions.explanation: Conical root - Carrot, Fusiform root - Radish, Napiform root - Turnip, Pneumatophores - Rhizophora (mangrove).

questions.question:
Match the aestivation type with the plant:
Column I: (a) Valvate (b) Twisted (c) Imbricate (d) Vexillary
Column II: (i) Pea (ii) Calotropis (iii) China rose (iv) Cassia
questions.explanation: Valvate - Calotropis, Twisted - China rose, Imbricate - Cassia, Vexillary - Pea (Fabaceae).

questions.question:
Match the family with its fruit type:
Column I: (a) Fabaceae (b) Solanaceae (c) Liliaceae
Column II: (i) Capsule or berry (ii) Legume or pod (iii) Berry or capsule
questions.explanation: Fabaceae produces legumes or pods. Solanaceae produces berries or capsules. Liliaceae produces capsules or berries.

questions.question:
Match the following leaf modifications with their functions:
Column I: (a) Tendrils in pea (b) Spines in cactus (c) Pitcher in Nepenthes (d) Fleshy leaves in onion
Column II: (i) Insect trapping (ii) Climbing (iii) Food storage (iv) Reduction of transpiration
questions.explanation: Tendrils in pea help in climbing. Spines in cactus reduce transpiration. Pitcher in Nepenthes traps insects. Fleshy leaves in onion store food.

questions.question:
Match the inflorescence type with its example:
Column I: (a) Raceme (b) Spike (c) Umbel (d) Capitulum (Head)
Column II: (i) Sunflower (ii) Mustard (iii) Centella (iv) Achyranthes
questions.explanation: Raceme - Mustard, Spike - Achyranthes, Umbel - Centella, Capitulum (Head) - Sunflower.

questions.question:
Match the families with their key androecium features:
Column I: (a) Fabaceae (b) Solanaceae (c) Liliaceae
Column II: (i) 6 stamens in two whorls (3+3) (ii) Diadelphous (9)+1 (iii) 5 epipetalous stamens
questions.explanation: Fabaceae has diadelphous (9)+1 stamens. Solanaceae has 5 epipetalous stamens. Liliaceae has 6 stamens in two whorls of 3 each.

questions.question:
Match the following terms with their descriptions:
Column I: (a) Hypogynous (b) Perigynous (c) Epigynous
Column II: (i) Ovary is inferior (ii) Ovary is superior (iii) Ovary is half-inferior
questions.explanation: In hypogynous flowers, the ovary is superior (e.g., mustard, China rose). In perigynous flowers, the ovary is half-inferior (e.g., plum, rose). In epigynous flowers, the ovary is inferior (e.g., sunflower, apple).

questions.question:
Match the common plants with their families:
Column I: (a) Tomato (b) Pea (c) Lily (d) Potato
Column II: (i) Liliaceae (ii) Fabaceae (iii) Solanaceae
questions.explanation: Tomato and Potato both belong to Solanaceae. Pea belongs to Fabaceae. Lily belongs to Liliaceae.

questions.question:
Match the fruit types with their examples:
Column I: (a) Drupe (b) Berry (c) Legume (d) Cypsela
Column II: (i) Pea (ii) Tomato (iii) Mango (iv) Sunflower
questions.explanation: Drupe - Mango, Berry - Tomato, Legume - Pea, Cypsela - Sunflower. These represent different types of true fruits.

questions.question:
How many of the following are root modifications?
Pneumatophores, Prop roots, Stilt roots, Rhizome, Bulb, Tuberous roots, Nodular roots
questions.explanation: Pneumatophores, prop roots, stilt roots, tuberous roots, and nodular roots are all root modifications. Rhizome and bulb are stem modifications, not root modifications.

questions.question:
How many of the following plants belong to Solanaceae?
Tomato, Potato, Brinjal, Petunia, Pea, Onion, Tobacco, Datura, Chilli
questions.explanation: Tomato, Potato, Brinjal (eggplant), Petunia, Tobacco (Nicotiana), Datura, and Chilli (Capsicum) all belong to Solanaceae. Pea belongs to Fabaceae and Onion to Liliaceae.

questions.question:
How many types of placentation are described in NCERT for flowering plants?
Marginal, Axile, Parietal, Free central, Basal, Superficial
questions.explanation: NCERT describes five types of placentation: Marginal (e.g., pea), Axile (e.g., china rose), Parietal (e.g., mustard), Free central (e.g., Dianthus), and Basal (e.g., sunflower). Superficial is not a standard NCERT type.

questions.question:
How many of the following are leaf modifications?
(i) Tendrils in pea (ii) Spines in cactus (iii) Thorns in Bougainvillea (iv) Pitcher in Nepenthes (v) Phyllode in Acacia (vi) Bladder in Utricularia
questions.explanation: Tendrils in pea, spines in cactus, pitcher in Nepenthes, phyllode in Acacia, and bladder in Utricularia are leaf modifications. Thorns in Bougainvillea are stem modifications, not leaf modifications.

questions.question: How many whorls are present in a typical complete flower?
questions.explanation: A typical complete flower has four whorls: Calyx (sepals), Corolla (petals), Androecium (stamens), and Gynoecium (carpels). These are arranged on the thalamus.

questions.question:
How many of the following are features of Fabaceae?
(i) Zygomorphic flowers (ii) Papilionaceous corolla (iii) Diadelphous stamens (iv) Marginal placentation (v) Fruit is a legume (vi) Superior ovary
questions.explanation: All six features are characteristic of Fabaceae (Papilionaceae): zygomorphic flowers, papilionaceous corolla (with standard, wings, and keel), diadelphous stamens (9+1), marginal placentation, fruit is a legume, and the ovary is superior.

questions.question:
How many of the following are examples of Liliaceae?
Onion, Garlic, Asparagus, Aloe, Colchicum, Tomato, Potato, Gloriosa
questions.explanation: Onion (Allium cepa), Garlic (Allium sativum), Asparagus, Aloe, Colchicum, and Gloriosa all belong to Liliaceae. Tomato and Potato belong to Solanaceae.

questions.question: Arrange the floral whorls from outermost to innermost:
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of floral whorls from outermost to innermost is: Calyx (sepals)  Corolla (petals)  Androecium (stamens)  Gynoecium (carpels). This is a fundamental concept in floral morphology.

questions.question: Arrange the following parts of a stamen from base to tip:
questions.explanation: From base to tip, a stamen consists of: Filament (stalk)  Connective (tissue connecting the two anther lobes)  Anther (bilobed structure containing pollen sacs).

questions.question:
Arrange the following from the outermost to the innermost layer of a seed:
(i) Embryo (ii) Testa (iii) Endosperm (iv) Tegmen
questions.explanation: From outermost to innermost: Testa (outer seed coat)  Tegmen (inner seed coat)  Endosperm (food storage tissue)  Embryo (innermost, the future plant).

questions.question:
Arrange the regions of a root from tip to base:
(i) Region of maturation (ii) Root cap (iii) Region of elongation (iv) Region of meristematic activity
questions.explanation: From the tip to the base, the root zones are: Root cap (protects the tip)  Region of meristematic activity (zone of cell division)  Region of elongation (cells elongate)  Region of maturation (root hairs develop, cells differentiate).

questions.question: Arrange the five petals of a papilionaceous corolla (Fabaceae) from largest to smallest:
questions.explanation: In the papilionaceous corolla of Fabaceae: the Standard (Vexillum) is the largest posterior petal, followed by two lateral Wings (Alae), and the two smallest anterior petals are fused to form the Keel (Carina).

questions.question:
Arrange the following from the outermost to the innermost layer of a drupe fruit:
(i) Seed (ii) Epicarp (iii) Endocarp (iv) Mesocarp
questions.explanation: In a drupe (e.g., mango), from outermost to innermost: Epicarp (thin outer skin)  Mesocarp (fleshy edible middle layer)  Endocarp (hard stony inner layer)  Seed (inside the stone).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events in the correct order during seed germination:
(i) Plumule emerges (ii) Seed absorbs water (iii) Radicle comes out first (iv) Seed coat ruptures
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: Seed absorbs water (imbibition)  Seed coat ruptures  Radicle (embryonic root) emerges first  Plumule (embryonic shoot) emerges afterwards.

questions.question: Nodular roots containing nitrogen-fixing bacteria (Rhizobium) are found in:
questions.explanation: Nodular roots are found in leguminous plants (Fabaceae). The root nodules harbour nitrogen-fixing bacteria Rhizobium which converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, making it available to the plant.

questions.question: The runners in grass are modifications of:
questions.explanation: Runners are sub-aerial stem modifications that grow horizontally along the soil surface. They have nodes from which roots and aerial shoots develop. Examples include grass (Cynodon), Oxalis, and Centella.

questions.question: A flower with both androecium and gynoecium is called:
questions.explanation: A bisexual (hermaphrodite or perfect) flower contains both male (androecium/stamens) and female (gynoecium/carpels) reproductive organs. Examples include mustard, rose, and pea.

questions.question: When carpels are free from each other, the condition is called:
questions.explanation: When the carpels of a gynoecium are free from each other (not fused), the condition is called apocarpous. When carpels are fused together, it is syncarpous. Apocarpous gynoecium gives rise to aggregate fruits.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a false fruit (pseudocarp)?
questions.explanation: Apple is a false fruit because the edible fleshy part develops from the thalamus (receptacle), not from the ovary. True fruits develop from the ovary wall (pericarp). Mango, tomato, and pea are all true fruits.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Onion is a stem modification, not a root modification.
Reason (R): Onion has a reduced disc-like stem with fleshy scale leaves storing food.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Onion is a bulb, which is an underground stem modification. It has a short, disc-like stem at the base surrounded by fleshy scale leaves that store food. The presence of a disc-like stem with nodes confirms it is a stem, not root.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): In Liliaceae, the ovary is superior.
Reason (R): In a superior ovary, the other floral parts are inserted below the ovary (hypogynous condition).
options: D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: In Liliaceae, the ovary is superior (hypogynous flowers). In this condition, the gynoecium is at the highest position and other floral parts arise below it on the thalamus.

questions.question:
How many of the following represent adventitious root modifications?
(i) Sweet potato (ii) Prop roots of banyan (iii) Stilt roots of maize (iv) Carrot (v) Pneumatophores of Rhizophora (vi) Turnip
questions.explanation: Sweet potato, prop roots of banyan, stilt roots of maize, and pneumatophores of Rhizophora are all adventitious root modifications. Carrot and turnip are tap root modifications.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the dicot seed is INCORRECT?
(i) It has two cotyledons.
(ii) The embryo consists of radicle, plumule, and embryonal axis.
(iii) Endosperm is always present in mature seeds.
(iv) The seed coat is derived from integuments.
questions.explanation: Statement (iii) is incorrect. In many dicot seeds (like pea, gram, bean), the endosperm is consumed during development and is absent in the mature seed (exalbuminous seeds). The food is stored in the cotyledons instead.

questions.question:
Match the following sub-aerial stem modifications with their examples:
Column I: (a) Runner (b) Stolon (c) Offset (d) Sucker
Column II: (i) Pistia, Eichhornia (ii) Chrysanthemum, Mentha (iii) Grass (Cynodon) (iv) Jasmine (Jasminum)
questions.explanation: Runner - Grass (Cynodon), Stolon - Jasmine (grows arching then touches ground), Offset - Pistia, Eichhornia (water plants, short thick runners), Sucker - Chrysanthemum, Mentha (underground runners that emerge).

questions.question:
How many of the following are characteristics of dicotyledons?
(i) Two cotyledons (ii) Tap root system (iii) Reticulate venation (iv) Trimerous flowers (v) Pentamerous or tetramerous flowers (vi) Parallel venation
questions.explanation: Dicot features: (i) two cotyledons, (ii) tap root system, (iii) reticulate venation, and (v) pentamerous or tetramerous flowers. Trimerous flowers (iv) and parallel venation (vi) are monocot features.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in order from an ovule to a mature fruit:
(i) Ovule (ii) Fertilized ovule (iii) Seed (iv) Fruit
questions.explanation: The developmental sequence is: Ovule (before fertilization)  Fertilized ovule (after fertilization, zygote forms)  Seed (ovule develops into seed)  Fruit (ovary develops into fruit enclosing the seed). The ovary wall becomes the pericarp.

questions.question: Opposite phyllotaxy is found in:
questions.explanation: In opposite phyllotaxy, two leaves arise at each node, lying opposite to each other. This arrangement is found in Calotropis (madar) and Guava. Mustard and sunflower show alternate phyllotaxy.
